title: Organic No Till Farming For Home Gardeners and Commercial Farmers

tasks.task: Conduct no-till farming for organic crops or home gardens
subtasks: Establish a cover crop (e.g., mix of cowpeas, forage radish, black mustard, oats, and buckwheat)
Use a roller to crush down the cover crop
Apply durable polypropylene fabric over the crushed cover crop
Secure fabric edges with water-filled hoses or sandbags
Remove fabric after one week, allowing decomposition of cover crop and weeds
Plant transplants (e.g., corn) through holes in the decomposed cover crop
Implement nematode control by using susceptible crops to attract and eliminate pests
Consider developing lightweight, electrically manipulatable fabrics for weed control
Monitor soil health, earthworm activity, and nutrient release

tasks.task: Demonstrate low-technology weed suppression for organic farming
subtasks: Use weed mats (light-excluding fabrics) to kill cover crops and weeds
Remove mats with water-filled hoses and replant (e.g., directly sow corn transplants)
Adapt existing home gardening techniques for easy weed suppression and soil conservation

tasks.task: Apply concepts of light exclusion for no-till weed control
subtasks: Cover existing vegetation with woven plastic fabric to deprive light
Remove fabric after desired period (e.g., one week), revealing decomposed cover crop
Leverage suppressed weeds to germinate under fabric and die off when uncovered
Repurpose weed-free soil for subsequent planting without tilling

tasks.task: Integrate cover cropping with organic farming practices
subtasks: Plant cover crops (diverse mix) prior to cash crop
Employ rolling and crimping to terminate cover crops (if necessary)
Apply light-excluding fabric to manage residual weeds
Facilitate cash crop establishment through holes or transplants in decomposed cover crop
